author: sonic.1337
content:
It's tough to see how we'll ever reach execution client diversity when even the (minority) client teams are sticking with Geth rather than using their own clients (or at least not Geth).

Source: <https://app.hex.tech/8dedcd99-17f4-49d8-944e-4857a355b90a/app/3f7d6967-3ef6-4e69-8f7b-d02d903f045b/latest?selectedStaticCellId=240dc734-931e-46e4-946a-89413b0abd8e>

**This data is about Lido operators**

author: ajsutton
content: I'd be extremely sceptical of any data that lists just "ConsenSys" as a single entity. I can think of at least four groups that large a decent number of nodes and make independent decisions over what to run.  When I was there, the two client teams run a variety of execution clients to test compatibility.

author: sonic.1337
content: True, the group working on Besu isn't necessarily the same group as the one in charge of the Lido validators. But it still feels a bit weird from my perspective, that an external solution (Geth) is used instead of an "in-house" one (Besu). Especially with the execution diversity problem at hand.

author: butta
content: Not a good look if any consensys-team is not using consensys-products -- besu in this case. If they don't use it, why would they expect others to?

author: ajsutton
content: eh, its a big place and I wouldn't want them to all be using one client regardless of which client it is. I'm not sure which subset of ConsenSys that data is trying to report on because it's definitely wrong to say they only use geth.

author: butta
content: idk, even lido marked the entity as consensys, <https://operators.lido.fi/>

author: ajsutton
content:
Maybe the problem here is really that we're assuming Lido operators are all of Ethereum...
Personally for decentralisation I'm more concerned that ConsenSys is running Lido validators than what they're running them with.
